headline: Podcast: Tech Selloff, Rate-Cut Worries
summary: Many big tech stocks logged a second day of declines, amid signs the Fed will hold interest rates steady in December. Plus: Disney reports lower-than-expected revenue. And Verizon gets a boost after announcing layoffs.

raw.headline: Podcast: Tech Selloff, Rate-Cut Worries

headline: Dow, Nasdaq, S&P 500 fall amid Fed rate cut worries
summary: US stocks (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) close Thursday's trading session in negative territory, led by the Nasdaq Composite's intraday losses of 2.29%. This all comes after President Trump signed a federal spending bill on Wednesday, effectively reopening the government. Yahoo Finance senior reporters Jared Blikre, Brooke DiPalma, Allie Canal, and Ines Ferré examine the day's market moves, noting the dip in Tesla (TSLA) and price action surrounding gold (GC=F) and bitcoin (BTC-USD). For full interviews, highlights, and key insights, check out more from Yahoo Finance Invest.

headline: Reports: Tesla to add Apple CarPlay & Verizon to trim workforce
summary: Yahoo Finance’s Brooke DiPalma recaps some of the top stories on Wall Street. Markets (^DJI, ^GSPC, ^IXIC) are taking a tumble as investors weigh the impact of the government shutdown on the economy and the path for rate cuts. Verizon (VZ) aims to reduce its workforce, reportedly cutting about 15,000 jobs, according to the Wall Street Journal. Tesla (TSLA) is making a move to add Apple CarPlay in its electric vehicles (EVs), according to Bloomberg. For full interviews, highlights, and key insights, check out more from Yahoo Finance Invest.

headline: Verizon to cut about 15,000 jobs as it restructures, source says
summary: By David Shepardson WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Verizon is planning to cut about 15,000 jobs as part of the company's restructuring efforts, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.

raw.headline: Verizon to cut about 15,000 jobs as it restructures, source says
raw.summary: By David Shepardson WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Verizon is planning to cut about 15,000 jobs as part of the company's restructuring efforts, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.

headline: Verizon to cut about 15,000 jobs as new CEO restructures, source says
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Verizon's new CEO is planning to cut about 15,000 jobs in the U.S. telecommunications company's largest ever layoffs, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on ​Thursday, outlining some of the executive's first efforts to restructure in the face of rising competition.  The wireless carrier faces mounting market ‌pressure amid concerns over a shrinking pool of new customers as older rivals offer cheaper plans and cable operators jump into the fray.  A Verizon spokesperson declined to comment.

raw.headline: Verizon to cut about 15,000 jobs as new CEO restructures, source says
raw.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Verizon's new CEO is planning to cut about 15,000 jobs in the U.S. telecommunications company's largest ever layoffs, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on ​Thursday, outlining some of the executive's first efforts to restructure in the face of rising competition.  The wireless carrier faces mounting market ‌pressure amid concerns over a shrinking pool of new customers as older rivals offer cheaper plans and cable operators jump into the fray.  A Verizon spokesperson declined to comment.

headline: Verizon to Cut About 15,000 Jobs
summary: Verizon Communications  is planning to cut roughly 15,000 jobs, looking to reduce costs as it contends with increased competition for wireless service and home internet, according to people familiar with the matter.  Verizon also plans to transition about 200 stores into franchised operations, which will shift employees off of its payroll.  Verizon, the largest U.S. telecommunications provider by subscriber base, faces a fierce battle for both wireless and home internet customers.

raw.headline: Verizon to Cut About 15,000 Jobs
raw.summary: Verizon Communications  is planning to cut roughly 15,000 jobs, looking to reduce costs as it contends with increased competition for wireless service and home internet, according to people familiar with the matter.  Verizon also plans to transition about 200 stores into franchised operations, which will shift employees off of its payroll.  Verizon, the largest U.S. telecommunications provider by subscriber base, faces a fierce battle for both wireless and home internet customers.
